text: My name is Matt Campbell.
At D2L, I work as an Engineering Director.

I run the foundation divisions, and currently
we are responsible for optimizing our core

product to prepare it and enable it to run more
smoothly within AWS.

The mission of D2L is to change the way the
world learns. So, we're an EdTech company.

We produce learning management software, similar
to what you would use if you took an online

course, or if your professor was putting documents
into the cloud for you to view when you were at home.
One of our chief business goals is to make sure that we are getting innovations out the door quickly.

Being all-in on AWS has allowed us to focus
on just one form of hosting for our software,

and it also provides us with a giant toolbox
of ready-made solutions that we can use to

enable the solutions that our clients actually
want.

One of the benefits that we experienced that
was, maybe, not expected, was it actually

brought our development and our operation
groups closer together, really for the first

time, in order to figure out the best way
to integrate ourselves with AWS.

So the three benefits that I look for in a
cloud provider... for me, chiefly, number
one, I want them to be innovative.

I want them pushing the envelope on what technology
can do. That's giving me new tools in my toolbox

that I can use to help push the envelope on
EdTech.
And AWS definitely hits the bill on that.

Year over year, they're releasing new technology
all the time that we're always amazed to see...
the cool things that are coming out.

And it excites us, as developers, that we
get to play with these tools and try to find

ways to integrate them together to produce
the things that our clients are going to love.

The second thing I'm looking for is ease of
use.

Day to day, I need my developers focused on
solving the business goals.

I don't want them spending heaps of cycles
trying to figure out, "How do I run this tool?"
"How do I integrate these two pieces together?"

The third thing I'm looking for is a bottom
line.

So, I need to have all those pieces delivered
to me but I need to be able to achieve my
budget needs.

By moving to AWS, we're consolidating down
on just one style of data center, which means

we no longer need to code multiple paths to
support different environments; things are
more uniform.

When I deploy within Canada, and when I deploy
within America, when I deploy within Europe,

we're getting the same results every single
time.

That means we have more time to spend on actually
improving our product, and less time on the plumbing.
